column1: 90178,Make a div fill the remaining screen space,"I am currently working on a web application, where I want the content to fill the entire screen. I have a header `div` and a content `div`. At the moment I am using a table for the layout like so:

Which works how I like. The table remains at 100%, and the `tdcontent` element is always less than 100%. Is there a way to achieve the same effect without using the `table`?",<table><css><html>,How to Make a Div Fill Remaining Screen Space Without Using Tables,"I'm developing a web application where I want a content `div` to occupy the remaining vertical space of the viewport after a header. Currently, I am using a table-based layout with the following structure:

This setup ensures that the table fills the entire viewport height, and the content cell is always less than 100%. However, I would like to achieve the same layout effect without using tables. How can I make a `div` fill the remaining vertical space of the viewport after a header `div` using modern CSS techniques?",<css><html><layout><flexbox><grid>

492994,Compare 2 dates with JavaScript,"can some one suggest a way to compare values of 2 dates greater then, less then and not in the passed using javascript. They values will be coming from text boxes

Thanks",<date><compare>,"How to Compare Two Dates in JavaScript for Greater Than, Less Than, and Not Equal Conditions","I'm working on a JavaScript project where I need to compare two dates entered by users through text boxes. I want to determine if one date is greater than, less than, or not equal to the other. Could someone suggest an efficient way to perform these comparisons? Any example code or best practices would be appreciated.",<javascript><date><comparison><user-input>
500504,"JavaScript ""For ...in"" with Arrays","I've been told not to use ""for...in"" with Arrays in JavaScript but never received a satisfactory reason as to why not.

The question is: Why is using ""for ...in"" with array iteration such a bad idea?",<javascript>,"Why is it problematic to use ""for...in"" loops for Array iteration in JavaScript?","I've heard that using ""for...in"" loops with Arrays in JavaScript is discouraged, but I haven't come across a clear explanation of why. Could someone explain the potential issues or drawbacks of using ""for...in"" for iterating over arrays? Are there better alternatives for array traversal?",<javascript><iteration><arrays>

1149703,Stacktrace to string in Java,Easiest way to convert the result of Throwable.getStackTrace() to a string that depicts the stacktrace?,<stack-trace><java><tostring>,How to Convert Throwable StackTrace to String in Java,I'm looking for the simplest way to convert the stack trace obtained from Throwable.getStackTrace() into a string that accurately depicts the full stack trace. Is there a straightforward method or utility in Java to accomplish this?,<java><stack-trace><exception>

2709821,python 'self' explained,"What is the purpose of the 'self' word in python. I understand it refers to the specific object created from that class, but i cant see why it explicitly needs to be added to very function as a parameter. To illustrate, in ruby, i could do this:
Which i understand, quite easily, However in python i need to include self:
Can anyone talk me through this? its not something ive come across in my (admittedly limited) experience.

Any help would be appreciated.",<python><self><explain>,Clarification on the Use of 'self' in Python Class Methods,"I'm trying to understand the purpose of the 'self' parameter in Python class methods. I know that 'self' refers to the specific instance of the class, but I don't quite understand why it needs to be explicitly included as the first parameter in every method.
For comparison, in Ruby, I can define a class like this:
which is straightforward. However, in Python, I need to include 'self' explicitly:

Could someone explain why Python requires 'self' to be explicitly specified in method definitions, and how it differs from Ruby's approach? Any clarification or resources would be appreciated.",<python><self><class-methods><object-oriented-programming>
3106452,java servlet instantiation and session variables,"Out of curiosity and naivety:

Suppose, I have a webserver which holds numerous servlets. For information passing among those servlets I am getting the servlet context and setting session variables. Now, if 2 or more users send request to this server then what happens to the session variables? Will they all be common for all the users or they will be different for each user. If they are different, then how was the server able to differentiate between different users?
If there are n users accessing a particular servlet, then this servlet gets instantiated only the first time the first user accessed it or it gets instantiated for all the users separately?

Thanks,",<servlets>,Understanding Servlet Instantiation and Session Variable Behavior in Java Web Applications,"I am working with a Java web server that hosts multiple servlets. I have a few questions regarding how session management and servlet instantiation work in this environment:

1. When multiple users send requests to the server, and I store data in session variables via the servlet context, are these session variables shared across all users or are they unique per user? How does the server distinguish between different users to maintain separate session data?

2. Regarding servlet instantiation: if multiple users access a particular servlet, is the servlet instantiated only once (e.g., on the first user request), or is a new instance created for each user? How does the server manage servlet instances in this context?
Any clarification on how session variables and servlet instantiation are handled in Java servlets would be appreciated.",<servlets><session-management><servlet-instances>

3289601,nulls object in Python?,How do I refer to the null object in Python?,<python><null>,How to Represent and Use Null Values in Python,"I'm trying to understand how to handle null or missing values in Python. Specifically, what is the standard way to refer to a null object or null value in Python? Are there built-in constants or objects I should use? Any examples would be helpful.",<python><null><null-value>
5844672,Delete an element from a dictionary,"Is there a way to delete an element from a dictionary in python?
I know i can just call `.pop` on the dictionary, but that returns the element that was removed. What im looking for is something returns the dictionary *minus* the element in question.

At present i have a helper function that accepts the dictionary in question as parameter, and then returns a dictionary with the element removed, i just wondered whether there was more elegant solution?",<python><dictionary><remove>,"How to Remove an Element from a Python Dictionary Without Modifying the Original

_","I'm looking for a way to remove an element from a Python dictionary without modifying the original dictionary. I know I can use the `.pop()` method, but it returns the removed element and alters the dictionary in place.

Currently, I have a helper function that takes a dictionary as input and returns a new dictionary with the specified element removed. However, I'm wondering if there's a more elegant or built-in way to achieve this, ideally without mutating the original dictionary.
Can anyone suggest a clean and efficient method to obtain a dictionary minus a specific key-value pair without changing the original?
9483757,END in git bash,"I'm trying to learn git with the help of git immersion http://gitimmersion.com/
But there's one thing that frustrates me whenever I use git log.

I can't figure out what to do next when I encounter this (END) word. I can't type any commands and I end up closing the current bash and open another. How do I type in the next command that I want to use?",<git>,"How to Exit the 'END' Prompt in Git Bash When Viewing Logs_

I'm following the Git Immersion tutorial (http://gitimmersion.com/) to learn Git, and I encounter an issue when using `git log`. When I view the log, I see a screen with the word `(END)` at the bottom, which I believe is part of the pager (less). However, I am unsure how to proceed from here. I cannot type commands or continue with my workflow, and I end up closing and reopening Git Bash.
Could someone explain how to properly exit the `(END)` prompt or pager so I can continue entering commands? Also, are there ways to configure the pager behavior in Git?
10123953,Sort Javascript Object Array By Date,"Say I have an array of a few objects:
var array = [{id: 1 date: Mar 12 2012 10:00:00 AM}{id: 2 date: Mar 8 2012 08:00:00 AM}]

How can I sort this array by the date element in order from the date closest to the current date and time down? Keep in mind that the array may have many objects, but for the sake of simplicity I used 2.

Would I use the sort function and a custom comparator?",<javascript><datetime>,How to Sort an Array of JavaScript Objects by Date in Descending Order from the Current Date,"I have an array of objects in JavaScript, each containing an 'id' and a 'date' property, like so:

I want to sort this array so that the objects are ordered from the date closest to the current date and time down to the furthest. The array may contain many objects, but for simplicity, I am illustrating with just two.

What is the best way to achieve this? Should I use the `sort()` function with a custom comparator? How do I handle parsing the date strings and ensuring the sorting is based on the actual date difference from now?",<javascript><date><sorting><array>
